The use of interactivity in a graduate class: A case study

This research examines a series of presentations, given by graduate students, in partial fulfillment of the requirements for a core class in a doctorate program of science education in a Southeastern university in the U.S.
Kahveci M. (2004). Society for Information Technology and Teacher Education (SITE).

The interactivity component of the course was mostly provided by the integration of WWW and computer software along with the student presentations. The interviews with four students and with the professor were digitally stored and transcribed for the data analyses. The advantages and disadvantages of the use of high level of interactivity were discussed.

Citation

Kahveci, M. (2004). The use of interactivity in a graduate class: A case study. In R. Ferdig, C. Crawford, R. Carlsen, N. Davis, J. Price, R. Weber & D.
